Award.AwardTitle: A New Structural Architecture for Recognition of DNA Damage

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is funded jointly by the Genetic Mechanisms Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences in the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry in the Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

Chemical modification and damage of DNA from a continual onslaught of cellular and environmental agents alters genetic information and threatens all aspects of cellular function. DNA repair proteins exist in all organisms to remove damaged DNA and protect the integrity of the genome. This research aims to understand at the atomic level how DNA repair proteins locate a particular type of DNA damage and initiate the process of fixing it. This program will enhance the educational benefits to society through 1) integration of research and education in the laboratory and the classroom, 2) vertical integration at all levels of training--from undergraduates to postdoctoral associates, 3) practical structural biology experience for undergraduates, 4) community outreach, and 5) participation by women and underrepresented groups, and 6) integration of science and art to enhance scientific communication. The close proximity of the College of Arts and Science and the School of Medicine at Vanderbilt University provides an exceptional collaborative training environment. Practical hands-on X-ray crystallography laboratory modules have been incorporated into the PI's courses to provide students with the unique opportunity to directly participate in all aspects of protein structure determination. All personnel associated with this research are involved in recruiting students from underrepresented groups from regional institutions, and the PI is involved in outreach through interactions with local high, middle, and elementary school students.

The long term goal of this research is to determine the mechanisms by which DNA repair enzymes locate and repair aberrant DNA. This research focuses on the structures and functions of a relatively new superfamily of DNA glycosylases, represented by the Bacillus cereus AlkD enzyme, that catalyzes the excision of cationic alkylated DNA nucleobases, including N3-methyladenine (3mA) and N7-methylguanine (7mG), which are among the most prevalent forms of DNA damage. Because of their inherent instability, the basis for recognition and removal of cationic alkylbases from DNA is unknown. The AlkD-related enzymes are unique in that they are the only DNA glycosylases specific for cationic lesions and with the ability to excise bulky modifications. Additionally, these enzymes are constructed from a tandem helical repeat architecture that has emerged as an important nucleic acid processing platform in chromatin remodeling and DNA damage response proteins. The PI's group has established that unlike other DNA glycosylases, AlkD does not need to flip the nucleobase target out of the DNA duplex prior to catalysis. Thus, the AlkD superfamily is an ideal system to study the fundamental requirements for base excision repair of alkylation damage repair, with strong potential to reveal novel mechanistic insight into DNA damage recognition. Four specific aims will integrate structural and computational biology, biochemistry, and genetic approaches to 1) determine the physicochemical features that underlie recognition and excision of cationic N3- and N7-alkylpurines, 2) elucidate the diversity among the AlkC/D superfamily that defines substrate specificity, 3) investigate how this unique damage recognition platform can excise bulky DNA adducts, and 4) understand the apparent redundancy between alkylpurine DNA glycosylase activities in Bacillus and to determine if AlkD participates in alternative repair pathways.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Alkylated DNA is a prevalent form of DNA damage arising from chemicals present in the environment and generated during normal cellular metabolism. This research program focused on understanding how a specific family of enzymes – typified by the bacterial HEAT-like repeat (HLR) DNA glycosylases AlkC and AlkD – locate and repair alkylated DNA. Using structural biology, biochemistry, and genetics approaches, we studied the substrate specificities, catalytic mechanisms, and cellular function of these enzymes.

Intellectual Merit: This award has resulted in 9 publications and led to several paradigm-shifting discoveries related to how DNA repair proteins locate and repair alkylated DNA. We discovered that base flipping is not required for lesion recognition and excision by DNA glycosylases, and that a non-base-flipping mechanism enables DNA glycosylases to excise bulky adducts. We trapped catalytic AlkD-DNA crystal structures representing various states along the catalytic trajectory and monitored catalysis of excision of a 3-methyladenine analog within the crystals. This was the first example of crystallographic monitoring of base excision by this type of DNA repair enzyme, providing exquisite details for AlkD’s unique catalytic mechanism. We also discovered that several prominent CH/π interactions in the active site contribute to catalysis of base excision. These interactions are ubiquitous in protein structures and commonly found at protein-DNA interfaces, and thus this work has helped advance our understanding of the enzymology of DNA processing in general. Third, we elucidated the details for how AlkD achieves exquisite activity for the bulky natural product yatakemycin, and how related enzymes from associated with other biosynthetic gene clusters interact with those compounds. Fourth, we found that AlkC excises nucleobases 3mC and 1mA, normally associated with a different repair pathway. We also discovered that AlkC utilizes a novel immunoglobulin-like (Ig) fold to enhance DNA binding, which helped explain the structural basis for AlkC’s unique substrate specificity.

Broader Impacts: This grant provided research support for 1 research assistant professor, 3 postdocs, 2 graduate students, 1 undergraduate, 2 high school students, 1 technician, and 1 laboratory manager. Of these, 2 are under-represented minorities (URM) and 7 are women. In addition to their research training, all students served as teaching assistants in at least one lecture course in the Department of Biological Sciences. Students attended and presented their research at weekly seminars associated with various programs and departments, and at annual regional and national meetings. This grant provided all trainees, including undergraduates and high school students, practical experience and exposure to X-ray crystallography and structural biology methods not usually taught at the undergraduate level. Trainees gave tours of the X-ray crystallization facility to guest students and teachers. All personnel associated with this grant published their work in top-tier scientific journals. Some received full financial support, and some leveraged this grant to obtain their own (e.g., graduate student Alyssa Rodriguez (URM) worked on this project for two months as a rotation student and, after joining the PI’s lab, received an NSF Graduate Research Fellowship). Students and postdocs that are no longer in the PI’s laboratory are now in medical school or in industry positions.
